thread.title: A more intimate, upscale way to cruise the Rhine
thread.title_full: A more intimate, upscale way to cruise the Rhine

author: Gene Sloan , USA TODAY
title: A more intimate, upscale way to cruise the Rhine
text:
Tour company Tauck's river ship Inspire sails on the Rhine and Moselle rivers between Amsterdam and Basel, Switzerland Tauck Fullscreen Tauck's Inspire docked in Koblenz, Germany on the Rhine. Tauck Fullscreen Tauck's 130-passenger Inspire pulls out of Amsterdam at the start of a 12-night sailing down the Rhine and Moselle rivers. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The captain of Tauck's Inspire, Hendrik Liemberg, welcomes passengers to the vessel during a cocktail reception at the start of the ship's voyage up the Rhine. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The welcome cocktail reception at the start of the Inspire's Rhine and Moselle sailing includes an introduction to the ship's senior staff. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Tauck passengers on the way to the Van Gogh-filled Kroller-Muller Museum during a stop in Nijmegen, The Netherlands. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A small group of Inspire passengers climb on bikes for a short ride during a stop at the Kroller-Muller Museum in the Netherlands. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A local guide leads Inspire passengers on a tour of Luxembourg during a day-trip to the city from the ship's docking point in Bernkastel, Germany. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Luxembourg's elegant Notre-Dame Cathedral is among the attractions for Inspire passengers during a walking tour of Luxembourg. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Inspire passengers stop for a photo along the remains of fortified walls that once encircled the strategically located city of Luxembourg. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A tour of Luxembourg concludes with a visit to the American Cemetery and Memorial, where more than 5,000 Americans who served in World War II are buried. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Inspire passengers admire one of the giant battlefield maps at the American Cemetery and Memorial in Luxembourg. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen An Inspire passengers pauses for a photo at the grave site of famed U.S. General George S. Patton, Jr., at the American Cemetery and Memorial in Luxembourg. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Inspire passengers walk the serene rows of graves at the American Cemetery and Memorial in Luxembourg. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Tauck's 12-night Rhine and Moselle cruise also includes a stop in Germany's oldest town, Trier. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Basilica of Constantine, or Aula Palatina, is among the highlights of a stop in Trier, Germany. It was built by Roman emperor Constantine at the beginning of the 4th century. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A local guide shows off Trier, Germany's Electoral Palace, often billed as one of the most beautiful Rococo palaces in the world. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Church of our Lady and adjacent St. Peter's Cathedral also are among top attractions during a walking tour of Trier, Germany. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Porta Nigra in Trier, Germany is the largest Roman city gate that survives north of the Alps Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen During a stop in Boppard, Germany, Inspire passengers have the chance to ride a chairlift up to a scenic overlook above the Rhine. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Inspire passengers take in the stunning views of a bend in the Rhine from an overlook above Boppard, Germany. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The view of a bend in the Rhine river from an overlook above Boppard, Germany. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Inspire passengers line the top deck of the ship as it sails into the UNESCOWorld Heritage-listed, castle-lined Middle Rhine Valley. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Two of more than a dozen castles that line the Rhine along a UNESCO World Heritage-protected stretch south of Boppard, Germany. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Inspire crew members serve up made-to-order smoothies and other snacks on the top deck of the vessel as it sails through the castle-lined Middle Rhine Valley. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen An Inspire crew member offers a smoothie to a passenger from a top-deck station as the ship sails past castles on the Rhine. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Inspire passengers snap photos of a castle from the top deck of the vessel. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Sailing through the castle-lined Middle Rhine Valley is a highlight of Tauck's 12-night Rhine and Moselle sailing. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen An Inspire passenger takes photos of castles as the ship sails through the historic Middle Rhine Valley. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A highlight of Tauck's 12-night Rhine and Moselle cruise is a private evening at one of the fortresses along the Middle Rhine Valley, Reichenstein Castle. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Inspire passengers pass through the gate into Reichenstein Castle for a private evening event. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The private evening for Inspire passengers at Reichenstein Castle includes a reception in its inner courtyard. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Inspire passengers explore Reichenstein Castle's private chapel during a private evening event at the hill-top fortress. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Reichenstein Castle's inner rooms are open exclusively to Inspire passengers during a private event. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen After a private reception and tour of Reichenstein Castle, Inspire passengers are treated to a dinner on the castle grounds. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Inspire passengers at a private dinner on the grounds of Reichenstein Castle, one of the highlights of Tauck's 12-night Rhine and Moselle cruise. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Inspire passengers visit the imposing ruins of Heidelberg Castle, which is perched on a hill overlooking Heidelberg, Germany. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Heidelberg Castle is home to the Heidelberg Tun, a famously giant wine vat that has room for more than 58,000 gallons of wine. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The view of Heidelberg from Heidelberg Castle. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The central square of Heidelberg. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Among the outings on the schedule for Inspire passengers on the Rhine is a private tour and reception at the historic Casino Baden-Baden. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A local guide takes Inspire passengers into the old part of Strasbourg, France near the end of the 12-night Rhine and Moselle cruise. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Strasbourg, France is home to a lovely, canal-lined historic area. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A local guide shows off some of the lovely homes in Strasbourg's historic district. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Pastries in Strasbourg, France. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Traditionally-garbed dancers take the stage for an Alsace folklore show on board Tauck's Inspire during a stop in Strasbourg, France. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Moet & Chandon champagne at the ready for the Captain's Farewell Reception at the end of Tauck's 12-night Rhine and Moselle voyage. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Upon entering the Inspire, passengers encounter a grand lobby area that is at the center of the ship's public areas and cabin decks. Tauck Fullscreen As is typical for river ships in Europe, the Inspire has one big, forward-facing lounge where passengers gather nightly for cocktails and entertainment. Tauck Fullscreen The Panorama Lounge also is home to nightly briefings where one of the ship's three tour directors map out plans for the coming day. Tauck Fullscreen A seating area in the Inspire's Panorama Lounge. Tauck Fullscreen A second, smaller lounge area called Arthur's is located at the back of the Inspire. It also doubles as a second eatery, serving an 'early risers' Continental breakfast and sit-down lunches and dinners. Tauck Fullscreen Named after Tauck chairman Arthur Tauck, Jr., Arthur's has a cafe-like setting and features its own dedicated kitchen. Tauck Fullscreen As is typical for river ships in Europe, the Inspire has one large main restaurant that can accommodate all 130 passengers on the ship at once. Tauck Fullscreen Among the most innovative and unusual cabins in the river cruise business are the Inspire's eight Category Three rooms found on the Emerald Deck, which offer a raised seating area next to soaring windows. Tauck Fullscreen The reception desk in the lobby of Tauck's Inspire. Tauck Fullscreen Unveiled in 2014, Tauck's 130-passenger Inspire is one of the most intimate and upscale river ships sailing in Europe. Tauck Shown here docked in Remagen, Germany, the Inspire sails on the Rhine and Moselle rivers between Amsterdam and Basel, Switzerland. (Photo: Gene Sloan, USA TODAY)
1 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE TRECHTINGSHAUSEN, Germany -- A lively reception is underway as Dean Scribner, 67, of Arlington, Va. arrives at the inner courtyard of Reichenstein Castle, an 11th century fortress overlooking the Rhine.
But despite free-flowing libations and plentiful hors d'oeuvres, the aerospace scientist and his companions from the Tauck river ship Inspire don't stay long. Wine glasses in hand, they soon are off to explore the four-floor-high, antique-filled stronghold's labyrinthine corridors, rooms and battlements.
For this one evening, at least, it is their own private citadel.
"It's wonderful to have this place all to ourselves," says Scribner, pausing to talk before a private dinner on the castle grounds. "These special events are an elegant way to see things."
Elegant, indeed. Long known for upscale tours on land, New England-based Tauck in recent years has been carving out a position as a leader in high-end river cruising with more intimate, exclusive and all-inclusive voyages than those offered by most other lines.
USA TODAY
Photo tour: Inside one of the most elegant ships on the Rhine
In addition to private events such as the evening at Reichenstein Castle, sailings on the Inspire and Tauck's six other vessels feature upscale cuisine, spacious accommodations and highly choreographed shore tours that often include special touches.
Starting with an overnight stay in Amsterdam, this 12-night "Rhine and Moselle" departure includes a private tour of the Van Gogh-filled Kroller-Muller Museum near Nijmegen, The Netherlands with an art historian. In the vineyard-surrounded Moselle river town of Cochem, Germany, passengers follow a visit to the picture-perfect Reichsburg Castle with a private tasting at a nearby winery.
"You go places other tour groups don't," says Tauck fan Larry Adams, 73, of Dallas, after a stop at the ruins of the Ludendorff Bridge over the Rhine, a World War II landmark that is located in the infrequently visited town of Remagen. "We wouldn't do a cruise with any other line."
A highlight of Tauck's 12-night Rhine and Moselle cruise is a private evening at one of the fortresses along the Middle Rhine Valley, Reichenstein Castle. (Photo: Gene Sloan, USA TODAY)
Among the unusual aspects of a Tauck sailing is the presence of three full-time tour directors in addition to the cruise director who serve as always-present guides, problem solvers, organizers and traveling companions. Most lines only staff vessels with a single cruise director.
Like other river lines, Tauck contracts with local guides to lead tours during most port stops. But the tour directors also accompany passengers on outings, backing up the local guides and assuring a seamless -- and classy -- experience. On a hot day in the ancient Roman city of Trier, Germany, one of the directors interrupts the local guides to buy the entire Tauck group ice cream at a local store. During a stop at the riverfront town of Boppard, Germany, another director takes a small group looking for more adventure up a nearby chairlift for a walk to a scenic overlooking -- and then buys everyone a beer.
While relatively new to river cruising, and a small player in the segment (river giant Viking has nearly 10 times as many ships), Tauck is no stranger to European touring, having operated land tours on the Continent for decades, and it's tapping its long-established connections with top local guides, attractions and restaurants in designing unusual cruise itineraries.
During a stop in Heidelberg, Germany, a visit to the imposing castle overlooking town is followed by brats and beer at an atmospheric brewpub just steps from the central square. In the Black Forest spa town of Baden-Baden, a walking tour ends with a private reception at the palatial Casino Baden-Baden.
Among the outings on the schedule for Inspire passengers on the Rhine is a private tour and reception at the historic Casino Baden-Baden. (Photo: Gene Sloan, USA TODAY)
The trip also includes a day in Luxembourg that features a stop at the American War Cemetery where famed American general George Patton is buried as well as an afternoon sailing through the castle-lined, UNESCO World Heritage-listed Middle Rhine Valley.
Like other Tauck ships, the Inspire offers unusually spacious cabins, with most rooms measuring 225 to 300 square feet. That's as much as 50% bigger than the typical cabin on other river ships.
A key factor in the Tauck difference is that the line configures its vessels for fewer passengers than other brands with similar size ships while maintaining similar staffing levels. Launched in 2014, the 443-foot-long Inspire carries a maximum of just 130 passengers. AmaWaterways and Avalon ships of the same length on the Rhine carry 34 to 36 more passengers, respectively, while similar ships operated by Viking pack in as many as 60 more people.
The result is a higher crew-to-passenger ratio that river cruise veterans aboard Inspire say brings more attentive service.
"They really go above and beyond," says Michelle Desio, 46, of Henderson, Nevada, who is trying Tauck for the first time after sailing with Viking and Uniworld.
Speaking on the Inspire's open-air top deck as it sails past the German cathedral town of Cologne, Desio says her room steward raced off when she mentioned she was low on water, only to return moments later with four complimentary bottles. Another passenger she knows asked for a decaffeinated tea that the ship didn't stock, and a crew member got off at the next port and bought some for her.
"Now that's service," she says.
Upon entering the Inspire, passengers encounter a grand lobby area that is at the center of the ship's public areas and cabin decks. (Photo: Tauck)
Notably, all tours during the voyage are included in the fare, which isn't always the case with river lines. In addition to meals, Tauck also includes unlimited complimentary beverages in its fares. Sodas, espresso drinks, wine, beer and even premium spirits are available for no extra charge at any time. Many other river cruise operators only offer complimentary wine and beer with lunch and dinner.
In addition, gratuities on Tauck as well as airport transfers are included in fares. So much is included, in fact, that the line doesn't even bother to swipe credit cards when passengers arrive. Many leave without a bill.
All of the extra perks and all-inclusiveness come at a price, alas. Fares for the Inspire's Rhine and Moselle cruises start at more than $400 per person, per day -- notably higher than many of its rivals. Similar 12-night sailings from Avalon start at around $322 per day, while Viking offers nine-night Rhine sailings starting for as little as $258.
Still, passengers on board aren't complaining.
"We would rather pay a little more and have a great experience, and that's what Tauck gives you," says Adams. "We're already looking at what will be our next Tauck cruise."
If you go ...
Tauck offers 12-night "Rhine and Moselle" sailings on the 130-passenger Inspire from April through October. The one-way voyages between Amsterdam and Basel, Switzerland start at $4,890 per person, based on double occupancy, including all tours; meals; airport transfers; unlimited on-board drinks throughout the day including wine, beer and premium spirits; and gratuities.
Tauck also offers shorter, seven-night "Romantic Rhine" sailings between Amsterdam and Basel starting at $3,590 per person. Beginning in 2016, Tauck also will offer a third itinerary between Amsterdam and Basel, "The Rhine, Swiss Alps & Amsterdam," that pairs a seven-night cruise with two nights at a hotel in Bern, Switzerland. The trips start at $4,690 per person.
Other Tauck river itineraries include 14-night sailings between Amsterdam and Budapest on the Rhine, Main and Danube rivers; seven-night sailings on the upper and lower Danube, often paired with included hotel stays and several days of touring on land; and voyages on the Seine and Rhone rivers in France.
Information: 800-468-2825; tauck.com .
For a deck-by-deck tour of Tauck's Inspire, click through the carousel below.
Unveiled in 2014, Tauck's 130-passenger Inspire is one of the most intimate and upscale river ships sailing in Europe. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Inspire is the first of Tauck's new Inspiration class of vessels that feature unusually large (for the industry) cabins and a high crew-to-passenger ratio. Here, the vessel's main entrance. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Upon entering the Inspire, passengers encounter a lobby area that is at the center of the ship's public areas and cabin decks. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Inspire's lobby is home to a reception desk as well as a travel desk staffed by the ship's cruise director. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A grand staircase at the rear of the lobby leads to three cabin decks as well as the ship's main dining room and other public areas. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen As is typical for river ships in Europe, the Inspire has one big, forward-facing lounge where passengers gather nightly for cocktails and entertainment. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Panorama Lounge also is home to nightly briefings where one of the ship's three tour directors map out plans for the coming day. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Located near the front of the Panorama Lounge is a semi-circular bar. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen As on other Tauck vessels, all drinks including wine, beer and premium spirits are available at any time for no extra charge -- an unusually all-inclusive policy that sets Tauck apart from many other river ship operators. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Clusters of seats near the front of the Panarama Lounge offer panoramic views over the ship's bow. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Panorama Lounge features live piano music nightly during cocktail hour and after dinner. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Just in front of the Panorama Lounge is a small outside deck area with built-in benches overlooking the ship's bow. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen As is typical for river ships in Europe, the Inspire has one large main restaurant that can accommodate all 130 passengers on the ship at once. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Dubbed the Compass Rose, the Inspire's main dining room is open for breakfast, lunch and dinner. It offers a mix of table sizes and passengers can sit where and with whom they wish. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A glass-walled wine cellar is located near the entrance to the Compass Rose. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A second, smaller lounge area called Arthur's is located at the back of the Inspire. It also doubles as a second eatery, serving an 'early risers' Continental breakfast and sit-down lunches and dinners. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Named after Tauck chairman Arthur Tauck, Jr., Arthur's has a cafe-like setting and features its own dedicated kitchen. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Arthur's also has a small bar that is staffed during mealtimes. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Coffee, tea and cookies are available in Arthur's around-the-clock at a self-serve station. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Puzzles at the ready for Inspire passengers in Arthur's. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The top deck of the Inspire features several seating areas including this one overlooking the bow of the vessel. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Inspire flies the German flag while sailing in Germany on the Rhine. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The captain of the Inspire navigates from a wheelhouse located near the front of the Sun Deck at the top of the vessel. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Just behind the wheelhouse is a seating area with glass partitions to keep out the breeze on windy days. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen More seating areas and lounge chairs are located toward the rear of the Inspire's Sun Deck. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Sun Deck also offers a lounge area open to the sun. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Also on the top deck of the Inspire near the rear is a putting green. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Just behind the putting green on the Inspire's Sun Deck is a small pool. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen One deck down from the dining room is a cluster of spa and fitness facilities that include a hair salon and a gym. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Inspire sails with a full-time hair stylist who works in the ship's dedicated hair salon. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Inspire has a dedicated treatment room for massages located next to the hair salon. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Across from the hair salon is a small fitness center with two treadmills, stationary bikes and free weights. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Inspire also has a sauna and steam bath located in a room next to the fitness center. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The interior of the steam bath. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A sauna is a relatively unusual feature for river ships in Europe, which are limited in size due to the dimensions of locks. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The interior of the Inspire's wood-lined sauna. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Inspire sails with several bikes that can be checked out at no charge during port stops. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Inspire has a small library of books located in a nook near passenger cabins. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Among the notable features of the Inspire are cabins that are more spacious than those of almost any other river ship. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A third of the Inspire's 67 cabins are suites measuring 300 square feet that feature bedrooms and separate sitting areas. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Suites feature large bathrooms with walk-in showers. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Suites also have large walk-in closets with rows of shelving and areas for hanging clothes. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Inspire features seven categories of cabins in all, including this Category Four cabin that measures 190 square feet. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Category Four rooms have contemporary bathrooms with a single sink, toilet and walk-in shower. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The walk-in shower in a Category Four cabin. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Inspire has three cabin decks that each offer two rows of outward-facing cabins divided by long corridors. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Smaller than the Inspire's 22 suites but still large by river ship standards are the ship's 10 Category Five cabins, which measure 225 square feet. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Category Five cabins have floor-to-ceiling French balconies with one sliding door that opens. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Category Five cabins feature a pillow top Queen-size bed that can be reconfigured as two twin beds. It measures 62 by 77 inches. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Category Five cabins have a sitting area with two chairs and a table. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Like other Inspire cabins, the ship's Category Five rooms have stylish, contemporary bathrooms. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A stairway leads down to the Emerald Deck, the lowest of Inspire's three cabin decks. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Among the most innovative and unusual cabins in the river cruise business are the Inspire's eight Category Three rooms found on the Emerald Deck, which offer a raised seating area next to soaring windows. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Category Three rooms on the Inspire measure 225 square feet, which is unusually large for cabins on the lowest level of a river ship. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Carved out of space from the deck above, the raised seating area in Category Three rooms is filled with light from soaring one-and-a-half-deck-high windows that open at the top. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Category Three rooms feature large, contemporary bathrooms with walk-in showers. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen High-end touches in Inspire cabin bathrooms include Villeroy & Bach sinks. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Walk-in showers in Category Three rooms feature a rainfall shower head as well as a traditional, wall-mounted shower head. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Bathrooms on Tauck's Inspire feature high-end Molton Brown toiletries. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Category Three cabins have built-in armoires along a wall near the bed. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The interior of the built-in armoire's in Category Three cabins have room for hanging clothes and drawers. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Built-in drawers in Inspire cabins offer plenty of storage space. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen All of the Inspire's cabins come with a miniature refrigerator stocked with complimentary water and soft drinks that is replenished daily. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Inspire cabins also have Nespresso espresso machines for passenger use. Coffee pods for the machines are complimentary and replenished daily. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Inspire cabins are wired with both U.S.-style and European-style outlets. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Inspire cabins feature side tables next to beds with iPhone docking stations. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Inspire passengers can open and close their cabin curtains from switches located next to the bed. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A control area on the wall of Inspire cabins lets passengers regulate the sound level of ship-wide announcements -- or turn them off completely. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Portable Vox audio systems located in each cabin allow passengers to listen to guides during shore excursions. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Like a growing number of river ships, the Inspire has a key slot near the door that activates the rooms lights and television. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Inspire's reception desk. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen Bins of umbrellas near the Inspire's reception desk are available for passenger use on rainy days. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Inspire offers a small store selling jewelry, scarves and other items, located in the lobby across from the reception desk. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Inspire has an elevator connecting all interior decks. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The interior of the Inspire's elevator has room for several people at once. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A relatively unusual feature of Tauck river cruises is the presence of Tauck buses that follow the ship from port to port for use during tours. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen The Inspire's ceremonial bell noting its christening in 2014 is located at the front of the vessel just outside the Panorama Lounge. Gene Sloan, USA TODAY Fullscreen A second, larger ship's bell is located on the Sun Deck.
